movie_cast: Peter Sellers, Ursula Andress, David Niven

movie_cast: Peter Sellers, Ursula Andress, David Niven

movie_cast: Peter Sellers, Ursula Andress, David Niven
short_review: If Casino Royale has what passes for its heart set on dealing the final death-blow to an over-worked legend, how sad that it didn't perform the necessary obsequies with style.

movie_cast: Peter Sellers, Ursula Andress, David Niven
short_review: Things pick up a little bit when Orson Welles, Peter Sellers, and Woody Allen stumble into the scene, but the total experience remains boringly incoherent.

movie_cast: Peter Sellers, Ursula Andress, David Niven
short_review: The melodrama has been staged on a lavish scale and everybody quite literally acts out the window.

movie_cast: Peter Sellers, Ursula Andress, David Niven

short_review: Proponents of this dreadfully indulgent cabaret, which thumbs its nose at coherence, have called its nigh-impenetrable plot the sincerest form of satire. That's like citing the indecipherable nature of Zapf Dingbats as a foremost send-up of language.

movie_cast: Peter Sellers, Ursula Andress, David Niven
short_review: A magnificent mess, it's either the greatest argument against LSD or the worst.

movie_cast: Peter Sellers, Ursula Andress, David Niven
short_review: Silly 007 spoof tamer than Austin Powers.

movie_cast: Peter Sellers, Ursula Andress, David Niven
short_review: Despite being not officially a Bond film this is good solid, entertaining action.

movie_cast: Peter Sellers, Ursula Andress, David Niven
short_review: Poor 007 is now lost in a hall of distorting mirrors.

movie_cast: Peter Sellers, Ursula Andress, David Niven
short_review: Chaotic and astonishingly unfunny.

movie_cast: Peter Sellers, Ursula Andress, David Niven
short_review: Peter Sellers has some amusing gags as the gambler, the chance of dressing up in various guises and a neat near-seduction scene with Ursula Andress.

movie_cast: Peter Sellers, Ursula Andress, David Niven
short_review: A mess. Casino Royale is two hours and eleven minutes of non sequitur.

movie_cast: Peter Sellers, Ursula Andress, David Niven
short_review: Out of five directors -- only McGrath manages to connect with this brontosaurian James Bond parody.

movie_cast: Peter Sellers, Ursula Andress, David Niven
short_review: Now Craig assumes the mantle, and you know, he does OK.

movie_cast: Peter Sellers, Ursula Andress, David Niven
short_review: No less than five directors, including John Huston, and eight writers, including Billy Wilder and Ben Hecht, tried to salvage this lengthy, laden all-star Bond spoof--to no avail.

movie_cast: Peter Sellers, Ursula Andress, David Niven
short_review: The few good aspects of this farce are vastly outweighed by the bad.

movie_cast: Peter Sellers, Ursula Andress, David Niven
short_review: It's cheesy, cheesy, cheesy.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Lois Chiles, Michaël Lonsdale
short_review: Yes, the final half-hour is utterly ridiculous, but the earthbound portion has much to recommend it.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Lois Chiles, Michaël Lonsdale
short_review: Vintage Bond has violence, innuendo, sexism, and peril.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Lois Chiles, Michaël Lonsdale
short_review: Frequently entertaining and grandiloquent in equal measure, Moonraker's overblown excess is a total joy.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Lois Chiles, Michaël Lonsdale
short_review: For the majority of the time, Bond and Goodhead seem quite pleased with their skills - and face very little serious adversity, even when regularly cornered by Jaws.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Lois Chiles, Michaël Lonsdale
short_review: Bond in space - that is all.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Lois Chiles, Michaël Lonsdale
short_review: Unquestionably the nadir to the whole Bond series.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Lois Chiles, Michaël Lonsdale
short_review: Upon reflection, I think I like it, purely as a film judged on its own merits, rather than judging it with the expectation of what film series its in...

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Lois Chiles, Michaël Lonsdale
short_review: ... the original scheme has been scrupulously respected... [Full review in Spanish]

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Lois Chiles, Michaël Lonsdale
short_review: The predictability of Moonraker is part of the pleasure. Like most Bond adventures, Moonraker is so overstated that it is camp, and so preposterous that it's fun.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Lois Chiles, Michaël Lonsdale
short_review: It's easy to see why 007 purists would loathe it, yet somehow 'Moonraker's' special brand of absurdity makes for one strangely entertaining Bond adventure.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Lois Chiles, Michaël Lonsdale
short_review: Moonraker, the newest James Bond spectacle, is a cheerful, splashy entertainment. The curators of the Bond museum do not surpass themselves with this exhibition, the 11th in the series, but they haven't fallen down on the job either.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Lois Chiles, Michaël Lonsdale
short_review: All that remains of the mood of the early films is the theme tune. And though Albert R. Broccoli, the producer, says that Bond goes on forever and never ages. the fact is that he is getting more juvenile with every film that's made.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Lois Chiles, Michaël Lonsdale
short_review: Too much of the budget is wasted on overblown spectacle, without enough attention being given to the basics.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Lois Chiles, Michaël Lonsdale
short_review: The series' spectacular photography, gimmickry, verve and wry wit are still abundant.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Lois Chiles, Michaël Lonsdale
short_review: Thank God for MOONRAKER!

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Lois Chiles, Michaël Lonsdale
short_review: James Bond would have to go back to Earth in "For Your Eyes Only" because "Moonraker" is truly a stuck-up, half-witted, scruffy-looking nerf herder.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Lois Chiles, Michaël Lonsdale
short_review: The "Bond In Space" angle is all we need to write Moonraker off as daft, but... the whole script is a messy disaster.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Lois Chiles, Michaël Lonsdale
short_review: Primo kids' stuff, but under-satisfying for adults. [Blu-ray]

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Lois Chiles, Michaël Lonsdale
short_review: Ludicrous but enjoyable hooey.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Lois Chiles, Michaël Lonsdale
short_review: One of the silliest and worse ones in the series.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Eva Green, Mads Mikkelsen
short_review: Casino Royale takes things back to the start for James Bond with a new actor and delivers one of the best films in the franchise.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Eva Green, Mads Mikkelsen
short_review: One of the best of all Bond movies, and the best in over a quarter century.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Eva Green, Mads Mikkelsen
short_review: A sharp script, lush direction, impeccable action, a memorably creepy Bond Villain, a bold and brilliant Bond Girl, and the arrival of Daniel Craig; Casino Royale is the greatest Bond film ever made.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Eva Green, Mads Mikkelsen
short_review: Craig delivers the first Bond who scares you.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Eva Green, Mads Mikkelsen
short_review: Casino Royale is right up there with my favourite films, let alone Bond films. Well paced, well shot, well acted and lots of fun and clever nods to past Bond-isms. Top marks.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Eva Green, Mads Mikkelsen
short_review: Insofar as a Bond film comes into contact with social and historical facts, it must turn them on their head, losing any of its charm in the process.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Eva Green, Mads Mikkelsen
short_review: You've never seen Bond like this before. Stand back, but stay watching.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Eva Green, Mads Mikkelsen
short_review: With its fresh approach to the lead character, its boost of severity, and its return to the source material, it proves to be the jumpstart the franchise has been begging for.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Eva Green, Mads Mikkelsen
short_review: In all the Bond movies, this is the most emotional and personal Bond adventure I've seen.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Eva Green, Mads Mikkelsen
short_review: I've been a fan of Craig since the little known Layer Cake and I am happy to say he does an outstanding job as Bond

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Eva Green, Mads Mikkelsen
short_review: 'Casino Royale' is not only the "best of all time" Bond movie, but also one of the strongest vehicles in the action genre we've seen since the beginning of the century. [Full Review in Spanish]

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Eva Green, Mads Mikkelsen
short_review: The film has breathless stunts and encounters aplenty.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Eva Green, Mads Mikkelsen
short_review: In Daniel Craig, the producers found a suitably tarnished and brutal icon for this new iteration of Bond

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Eva Green, Mads Mikkelsen
short_review: James Bond is back, and as it turns out, he's been gone a lot longer than anyone even realized.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Eva Green, Mads Mikkelsen
short_review: Bond is back. Bond is beefy. And the new Bond is blond. Daniel Craig has comfort ably slipped into the tuxedo, size 007, and left audiences shaken and stirred.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Eva Green, Mads Mikkelsen
short_review: When Bond kills an adversary in a hotel stairwell, the violence is nasty and brutal - and you feel bystander Vesper's shock and revulsion too. She doesn't merely wince and get over it, as so many of her predecessors did; she's clearly traumatised.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Eva Green, Mads Mikkelsen
short_review: Casino Royale is exactly what the franchise needs to keep in the game against the Bournes and Missions: Impossible of the world.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Eva Green, Mads Mikkelsen
short_review: This is a much more serious Bond than we've seen in many years. Daniel Craig inhabits the dark side of the secret agent really well, he is absolutely the best Bond since Connery.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Eva Green, Mads Mikkelsen
short_review: Craig's humanised, more flawed interpretation of the role balances Campbell's physical direction and co-writer Paul Haggis's sparing wit, while Eva Green provides an alluring love interest.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Eva Green, Mads Mikkelsen
short_review: I think this is a very intelligent film for a Bond film, and certainly one of the most enjoyable.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Jill St. John, Charles Gray
short_review: It would be Connery's final appearance in the official series, and he goes out in style.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Jill St. John, Charles Gray
short_review: Diamonds Are Forever might not be the greatest showcase for Connery's talents, but it's still an enjoyable outing in its own right, one that values humor over thrills.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Jill St. John, Charles Gray
short_review: This might be the last time for another several features that Bond actually feels like a secret agent.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Jill St. John, Charles Gray
short_review: Maybe I'm doing Diamonds a disservice. There are some fun moments and some silly moments that I can't defend (like multiple Blofelds) but sadly I felt cheated (and still do) on what this film could have been.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Jill St. John, Charles Gray
short_review: How good it was to see the gadgets again, the gymnastic grace of the fantasy-violence, the comedy of the imaginary sex, and that quality of the Bond pictures at their best which I can only call geniality.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Jill St. John, Charles Gray
short_review: Has some dramatic merit and is one of the better films in the entire franchise.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Jill St. John, Charles Gray
short_review: The script is poor, the comedy ill-timed and the ending anticlimactic. What more can I say?

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Jill St. John, Charles Gray
short_review: Has its flaws, but being a boring Bond movie isn't one of them. It may not hit top tier status, but Connery makes "Diamonds Are Forever" another gem in the 007 mythos.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Jill St. John, Charles Gray
short_review: Connery's last official Bond film is energetic but violent.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Jill St. John, Charles Gray
short_review: After an hiatus, Sean Connery was lured back to the series with a huge paycheck but the end result is decidedly a mediocre feature.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Jill St. John, Charles Gray
short_review: After struggling with a few films to find the right vibe and tone for a Bond film, DIAMONDS ARE FOREVER finds a nice balance that would work for a while.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Jill St. John, Charles Gray
short_review: Thanks to the clarity and cut of past 007 films, Sean Connery will sparkle forever. But with a dearth of action and only a fat paycheck as motivation, "Diamonds" feels less like a triumphant return and more like a cheesed-up cabaret version of Bond.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Jill St. John, Charles Gray
short_review: Makes the disastrous, franchise-altering decision to underscore how fusty Bond is by diving right into campines.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Jill St. John, Charles Gray
short_review: The clumsily executed climax reduces the quality of the film considerably.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Jill St. John, Charles Gray
short_review: Bond looks better than ever, partly because Sean Connery has returned to play him.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Jill St. John, Charles Gray
short_review: Next door to glass, but aided by the return of Connery.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Jill St. John, Charles Gray
short_review: Connery has a ball with great stunts, snappy dialogue and a bevy of typically Bondish beauties.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Jill St. John, Charles Gray
short_review: Fairly forgetable addition to the 007 series, bringing Connery's tenure to a unsatisfying close.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Jill St. John, Charles Gray
short_review: Diamonds Are Forever doesn't carry the same quality or flair as its many predecessors.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Jill St. John, Charles Gray
short_review: Assorted ladies, a few quick lines, and one good chase, making for a mediocre entry in the series.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Halle Berry, Toby Stephens
short_review: Not as bad as its reputation, with Brosnan finally appearing completely at ease in the part.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Halle Berry, Toby Stephens
short_review: Die Another Day is largely overblown with no real sense of closure, and the series needed to undergo some massive DNA replacement therapy before it was fit for duty once again.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Halle Berry, Toby Stephens
short_review: It is simply so outlandish and unbelievable that it becomes difficult to care about the story.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Halle Berry, Toby Stephens
short_review: Sadly, the introductory scene is far better than anything else in the picture; it desperately deserves a grander movie to herald.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Halle Berry, Toby Stephens
short_review: This film is bad - seriously and shockingly bad.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Halle Berry, Toby Stephens
short_review: It's definitely [Pierce] Brosnan's worst Bond film.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Halle Berry, Toby Stephens
short_review: Die Another Day is a tale of two halves, the first half is mostly good, the second is nearly always awful. This is how Pierce Brosnan's Bond goes out, which is a damn shame.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Halle Berry, Toby Stephens
short_review: With work like this, I'm sure #21 can't be too far behind. Thank goodness Brosnan isn't ready to throw in the towel yet. Better keep those martinis comin' folks. And make that shaken, not stirred.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Halle Berry, Toby Stephens
short_review: The film is a frantic roller-coaster ride from which you emerge exhausted, with a massive blur in the head.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Halle Berry, Toby Stephens
short_review: this incarnation of Bond is just plain fun

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Halle Berry, Toby Stephens
short_review: Plenty entertaining, but consistent with most of Brosnan's Bonds, a few misguided decisions keep it from being a classic.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Halle Berry, Toby Stephens
short_review: By honoring the Bond iconography of girls, guns and cars, Tamahori and the screenwriters are able to do something new with Bond: They dare to suggest that Bond is not only human, but also fallible.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Halle Berry, Toby Stephens
short_review: It's the same old Bond.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Halle Berry, Toby Stephens
short_review: Die Another Day faithfully hews to the James Bond formula, giving us all the elements and allowing the '60s formula to not only live, but prosper, into the the new millennium.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Halle Berry, Toby Stephens
short_review: Tamahori senses what Bond fans have been missing. He and Brosnan deliver it with style, both deserving to try another day.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Halle Berry, Toby Stephens
short_review: Adding to the grimness: The title song is from Madonna, a dreary bit of lightweight electro-pop that goes on and on to little effect.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Halle Berry, Toby Stephens
short_review: Strange, is it not, how the regular bombardment of thrills can have quite the opposite effect of the one intended.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Halle Berry, Toby Stephens
short_review: In a year when Austin Powers has scoffed at 007 as a joke and xXx has scoffed at him as an anachronism, Die Another Day is a fluffed opportunity to assert that nobody does it better.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Halle Berry, Toby Stephens
short_review: A vigorous 20th installment that is as strong on action as it is weak on the interpersonal stuff.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Halle Berry, Toby Stephens
short_review: James Bond gets bad news in Die Another Day: They've rescinded his license to kill. The news is worse for us. They've given him license to bore.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Ursula Andress, Joseph Wiseman
short_review: The first movie to feature Ian Fleming's iconic secret agent seems almost quaint when compared to the pictures that followed, but that's hardly meant as a knock.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Ursula Andress, Joseph Wiseman
short_review: It's like a prototype requiring polishing; and more than twenty subsequent films would keep reshaping and perfecting that template.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Ursula Andress, Joseph Wiseman
short_review: This is the birth of Bond and the beginning of something special.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Ursula Andress, Joseph Wiseman
short_review: Stylish, armed with handsome production values, and sporting a confident lead actor, Dr. No is a strong entry point, elemental in kickstarting the global phenomenon we know and love.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Ursula Andress, Joseph Wiseman
short_review: This is the first of lan Fleming's droll, nasty and absorbing spy thrillers to reach the screen. It augurs well for the future of the series.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Ursula Andress, Joseph Wiseman
short_review: The first half hour I took to be a fairly good spoof on sex-espionage films in general... Then James Bond lands on Dr. No's atomic island and science fiction takes over with lethal results in every sense of the word.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Ursula Andress, Joseph Wiseman
short_review: Brilliant lead actor and villain hold the film together, despite a few flaws. The fact that it got so much right from the start is a real testament to the film series.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Ursula Andress, Joseph Wiseman
short_review: Dr. No is a solid, if unspectacular, start to the longest-lived movie series of all time

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Ursula Andress, Joseph Wiseman
short_review: If you've given up on the many iterations of the Bond franchise, it's worth shaking off all that adaptation decay and going back to the original, which is more fun and less sexist than many of the later films.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Ursula Andress, Joseph Wiseman
short_review: It reads like a serial and plays the same way, quite as if it were several chapters of genuine cliff-hanger compressed into one feature picture. The action is there, as rapid as the movement of a flapping window blind in a hurricane.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Ursula Andress, Joseph Wiseman
short_review: Of course, it's dated -- a Sunbean Alpine isn't exactly cutting edge transport -- but the elegant playboy spy with just a whiff of danger was clearly here to stay.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Ursula Andress, Joseph Wiseman
short_review: The James Bond series started in great style with this cleverly conceived dose of sheer escapism that, unlike later episodes, remained true to the essence of Ian Fleming's super-spy novels.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Ursula Andress, Joseph Wiseman
short_review: About as perfect a franchise-starter as you could imagine and certainly accomplishes the task of leaving you eagerly anticipating Bond's next adventure.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Ursula Andress, Joseph Wiseman
short_review: The first James Bond cast a relatively unknown actor, Sean Connery, who forever defined 007 as a cool, suave, womanizing agent, adept at delivering witty one liners.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Ursula Andress, Joseph Wiseman
short_review: The film geek in me wants to praise it, but the film critic in me wants to expose its flaws. I still have a soft spot for it, but if I'm being truly honest, it's kind of lackluster.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Ursula Andress, Joseph Wiseman
short_review: In the end, it's more gumshoe mystery than action-adventure and, comparative to almost everything that followed, very low-key. But legends must start somewhere, and looking back at its reminders of how Bond wasn't always "Bond" are fascinating.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Ursula Andress, Joseph Wiseman
short_review: The low-key mystery plot and the resolutely human-sized drama of it all makes this one of the sanest of all Bond pictures.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Ursula Andress, Joseph Wiseman
short_review: 007's silver screen debut. Not for young kids.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Ursula Andress, Joseph Wiseman
short_review: It's terrific entertainment, to be sure, but its unevenness keeps up from being a great film.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Ursula Andress, Joseph Wiseman
short_review: Capably brings together Caribbean travelogue, Gropius-type architecture, and cardboard computers with "danger level" plaques

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Carole Bouquet, Topol
short_review: The scripting is strong in this woefully underrated entry.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Carole Bouquet, Topol
short_review: For Your Eyes Only is still the most thrilling entry in Roger Moore's tenure. A great song, a charming ally, a creepy henchman, a terrific Bond Girl, and a genuine espionage mission - what's not to love?

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Carole Bouquet, Topol
short_review: One of the more unspectacular entries in the series.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Carole Bouquet, Topol
short_review: This is definitely one of Roger Moore's best outings as Bond. Whilst Moore is naturally a charmer, in For Your Eyes Only, he presents Bond with a tougher edge.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Carole Bouquet, Topol
short_review: The picture can't quite shake off the increasingly silly legacy which had mired the franchise in the Roger Moore era.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Carole Bouquet, Topol
short_review: Some really good set pieces and some fun new characters round out a good entry into the Bond series, even if it does suffer from a bit of an identity crisis.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Carole Bouquet, Topol
short_review: For Your Eyes Only, however, looks like the work of people too smug in the belief they've got a good thing going to bother to make it interesting. It oozes unwarranted condescension.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Carole Bouquet, Topol
short_review: Most of the time, though, For Your Eyes Only is a slick entertainment.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Carole Bouquet, Topol
short_review: No. 12 in the phenomenally durable James Bond series. For Your Eyes Only is undeniably easy on the eyes. Maybe too easy to prevent the mind from wandering and the lids from drooping.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Carole Bouquet, Topol
short_review: This 12th entry in the 007 series provides no real surprises, with the exception perhaps of Roger Moore, who gets the chance to show a little more grit than usual.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Carole Bouquet, Topol
short_review: After 20 years, though, it's comforting to have 007 still stylishly triumphant and making the theaters safe for entertainment.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Carole Bouquet, Topol
short_review: This is the one of the better stripped down Bond films. It's not flashy, the villains are grounded and Moore dials his take on 007 down significantly.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Carole Bouquet, Topol
short_review: Gone are the big gadgets and huge set pieces. What we get instead are some decent car chases, fist fights, and practical stunts. The result is a pretty satisfying Bond entry.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Carole Bouquet, Topol
short_review: The grittiest Roger Moore Bond, it's an under-rated, gadget-light and stunt-heavy return to Cold War action.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Carole Bouquet, Topol
short_review: There are quite a few individual pieces of "For Your Eyes Only" that don't quite fit. But to borrow from its Olympic theme, its gymnastic flexibility sure lets it excel in the all-around.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Carole Bouquet, Topol
short_review: [Finds] a way to make even Moore's breezy quipping work in a more sober vein. It's serious without sacrificing escapist fun.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Carole Bouquet, Topol
short_review: Sea and ski with 1981's Bond in an average outing.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Carole Bouquet, Topol
short_review: It's the only Bond film where M didn't appear.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Carole Bouquet, Topol
short_review: First-time director John Glen knows what's needed to create suspense...put the series' trademark wit, women, and song alongside the high-stakes adventure of a more brutal 007. [Blu-ray]

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Carole Bouquet, Topol
short_review: ...suffers from a disastrously plodding midsection that ultimately casts a pall over the remainder of the proceedings...

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Daniela Bianchi, Robert Shaw
short_review: A highly immoral film in every imaginable way but it sure is fun...

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Daniela Bianchi, Robert Shaw
short_review: Sean Connery's favorite Bond movie is based on John F. Kennedy's favorite Bond book, and who are we to argue with their tastes?

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Daniela Bianchi, Robert Shaw
short_review: The second Bond film was already too self aware to remember to be itself.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Daniela Bianchi, Robert Shaw
short_review: The story moves too slowly, fattened up with activities that are inconsequential and not action oriented.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Daniela Bianchi, Robert Shaw
short_review: From Russia with Love is just an exciting film from start to finish.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Daniela Bianchi, Robert Shaw
short_review: From Russia with Love is a complete and total success as both a Bond film and a spy film, loftily enjoying the best of both worlds as it further establishes an indomitable template for more adventures to come.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Daniela Bianchi, Robert Shaw
short_review: A comedown from Dr. No, whose brisk parody here slackens into a queasy compromise with the real thing that tries to have it both ways and so fails to have it either way.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Daniela Bianchi, Robert Shaw
short_review: It has a few sillier moments, but in general it's quite the tense cold war spy film, with some good foreshadowing and a few really good action set pieces.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Daniela Bianchi, Robert Shaw
short_review: From Russia With Love perfectly threads the needle between art and commerce, showing us everything that's allowed the series to keep on keeping on.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Daniela Bianchi, Robert Shaw
short_review: The pace fast and furious and the invention, I suppose, inventive in the sense that a new nonsense always follows hard on the heels of an old nonsense and blow follows blow in crunching virtuosity of method.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Daniela Bianchi, Robert Shaw
short_review: Cliff-hanging, 1964: that's From Russia with Love. That is, you get a complete serial every five minutes, often with a new babe or two falling for James Bond's masculine charms.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Daniela Bianchi, Robert Shaw
short_review: The series' tightest expression of brutes playacting as gentlemen

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Daniela Bianchi, Robert Shaw
short_review: The success of Dr. No has no doubt given the James Bond team added confidence, if that was necessary, and From Russia with Love is made by people who clearly know that they now have a gilt-edged formula to play with.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Daniela Bianchi, Robert Shaw
short_review: Everything that worked in DR. NO is fully realized here. Sean Connery is 10 times more confident here as 007, oozing charm and masculinity.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Daniela Bianchi, Robert Shaw
short_review: The second Bond is one of the best in the series, due to the intriguing plot, sinister villains, and fabulously staged fight aboard the Orient Express.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Daniela Bianchi, Robert Shaw
short_review: It has more in common spiritually with Le Carre than Fleming. Only after James Bond's vulnerabilities have been further exploited than in "Dr. No" does he succeed. "Russia" is about as far as it gets from the biggest Bond, but it's easily the best.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Daniela Bianchi, Robert Shaw
short_review: One of just a couple Bond adventures that is genuinely great as cinema.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Daniela Bianchi, Robert Shaw
short_review: Creative Cold War Bond thriller is best for teens and up.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Daniela Bianchi, Robert Shaw
short_review: It's not too different from the non-Bond action thrillers of the same era, in which company it falls well short of the top film, North by Northwest. Plenty of period charm, though, and a few of the Bond franchise's most Austin Powers-esque moments.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Daniela Bianchi, Robert Shaw
short_review: Much of it borders on the inept and the embarrassing, and that goes for the title song sung by Matt Monro, the "singing bus-driver".

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sean Bean, Izabella Scorupco
short_review: The best bit of casting is Famke Janssen as Xenia Onatopp, who equates sex and death more than any other Bond character.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sean Bean, Izabella Scorupco
short_review: ...sets the stage for the rough-edged, real-world 007 we would eventually get.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sean Bean, Izabella Scorupco
short_review: GoldenEye was a massive return to form, modernizing Bond for a new era of filmgoers and introducing Pierce Brosnan to the role.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sean Bean, Izabella Scorupco
short_review: In trying so hard to distance itself from old Bonds, Goldeneye is also now a relic of the post-Cold War era.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sean Bean, Izabella Scorupco
short_review: The tank chase through St. Petersburg is perhaps the greatest action scene in any Bond film to date.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sean Bean, Izabella Scorupco
short_review: Goldeneye never loses sight what this film is about. The spy game is all about secrets and betrayal and if you are a spy - keep your friends close and your enemies closer. Goldeneye epitomizes that phrase.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sean Bean, Izabella Scorupco
short_review: The interplay between Alec and Bond, the cast of oddball characters, the great set pieces. GoldenEye enjoyable for its entire runtime.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sean Bean, Izabella Scorupco
short_review: With a dynamite opening reel that showcases the series renewed vigor, GoldenEye is two hours of well-executed thrills, high-tech mayhem and one-of-a-kind comedy.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sean Bean, Izabella Scorupco
short_review: Some elements of the story are a little silly - though I love Famke Janssen's portrayal of Xenia Onatopp, her psychopathic, nymphomaniac pathology is slightly comical.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sean Bean, Izabella Scorupco
short_review: GoldenEye, the 17th in the series and first in six years, gives 007 a new lease on life. Pierce Brosnan is no Sean Connery, but he is the best Bond since Connery started it all with Dr. No in 1962.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sean Bean, Izabella Scorupco
short_review: It's a thoroughly fun film overall, though, and ranks as something of a forgotten gem 25 years later.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sean Bean, Izabella Scorupco
short_review: With the ideal Bond, a worthy adversary, gorgeous Bond Babes and a director skilled enough to fully maximize their potential, this stands atop the rest as the best Bond film.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sean Bean, Izabella Scorupco
short_review: It contains four or five humorous, intricately choreographed action sequences that -- while not as riveting as similar episodes in True Lies or Die Hard With a Vengeance -- are enjoyable on that idiot level that even critics possess.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sean Bean, Izabella Scorupco
short_review: James Bond, the British spy with a taste for the high life and a license to kill, comes back in surprisingly hardy and supple form.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sean Bean, Izabella Scorupco
short_review: Brosnan's right there, born to play the part. Perhaps by design, he captures a bit from each predecessor -- the panache of Sean Connery, the cheeky humor of Roger Moore, the serious grit of Timothy Dalton.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sean Bean, Izabella Scorupco
short_review: At the most basic, crowd-pleasing level, Goldeneye does the trick.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sean Bean, Izabella Scorupco
short_review: Giving 007 a sleek bullet of a BMW instead of his trusty old Aston-Martin isn't exactly going to turn the world of Bond upside down. And, as it turns out, neither does the casting of Brosnan.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sean Bean, Izabella Scorupco
short_review: In GoldenEye, [Brosnan's] performance achieves darker, Conneryesque tones. And the movie's relatively realistic take on Bond -- realistic, that is, by the series' flamboyant standards -- helps to give his work weight.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sean Bean, Izabella Scorupco
short_review: James Bond's latest outing is big, and it's brash -- in short, it's double-oh-fun.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sean Bean, Izabella Scorupco
short_review: Basically, James, GoldenEye wasn't bad. A bit long and not the sexiest or most thrilling Bond movie. But a Bond movie nonetheless, and far from an embarrassment like Moonraker.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Gert Fröbe, Honor Blackman
short_review: It's the easy choice. The obvious choice. The safe choice. It's also the best choice, a no-brainer.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Gert Fröbe, Honor Blackman
short_review: Goldfinger was the third film in the James Bond franchise but the film, starring Sean Connery, is the gold standard for all Bond films.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Gert Fröbe, Honor Blackman
short_review: Bond is ordered to remain cold and objective but disobeys handsomely, seducing and bedding almost every woman in the film.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Gert Fröbe, Honor Blackman
short_review: I know we all have our favourites but the Bond franchise wouldn't be what it is today without Goldfinger.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Gert Fröbe, Honor Blackman
short_review: It's not quite the perfect film many claim it to be, but it is a perfect representation of what Bond is, and you would be hard-pressed to identify a film in the series that is filled with more iconic moments than this one.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Gert Fröbe, Honor Blackman
short_review: The stoic, tongue-in-cheek style in this third 007 flick was culturally defining.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Gert Fröbe, Honor Blackman
short_review: The third, and by far the best, of the Bond jobs.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Gert Fröbe, Honor Blackman
short_review: Parts of the film are so classically dramatic they could function as silent pieces - like when Bond infiltrates Goldfinger's plant in Switzerland and the Fort Knox raid.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Gert Fröbe, Honor Blackman
short_review: Goldfinger is a classic, no doubt. It does have some flaws in the third quarter of the film, but it pulls it back to become a fun, relaxing watch.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Gert Fröbe, Honor Blackman
short_review: The ultimate measure of Goldfinger's sustained success is in how much it's become part of our shared filmic culture irrespective of whether folks have even seen the movie.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Gert Fröbe, Honor Blackman
short_review: Goldfinger allows nothing to impede its sense of humour: it converts Bond into a human equivalent of the cat in the Tom and Jerry cartoons, with the same ghastly resilience and the same capacity for absorbing punishment.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Gert Fröbe, Honor Blackman
short_review: This is the third, tightest and wildest script Sean Connery, as the invincible agent, has yet had on the screen.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Gert Fröbe, Honor Blackman
short_review: It's phenomenal!

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Gert Fröbe, Honor Blackman
short_review: Goldfinger really is a dazzling object lesson in the principle that nothing succeeds like excess.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Gert Fröbe, Honor Blackman
short_review: [VIDEO ESSAY] "Goldfinger" set in stone the formula for what would become cinema's longest running and most reliably entertaining franchise. Regardless of how many installments have come since, "Goldfinger" retains its reputation as the best of the bunch.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Gert Fröbe, Honor Blackman
short_review: All the tropes are genre highs, from the iconic title song to the archetypal cool car to the endlessly quotable sadistic one-liners.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Gert Fröbe, Honor Blackman
short_review: Ours not to reason why with "Goldfinger"; ours but to gape and admire; which is very easy and enjoyable until the story's iceberg of extravagance finally appears in its true proportions.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Gert Fröbe, Honor Blackman
short_review: For 007 fans or action adventure/spy movie fans in general, it really doesn't get much better than "Goldfinger," a tremendous blockbuster that entertains on every level.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Gert Fröbe, Honor Blackman
short_review: GOLDFINGER, for me, isn't the perfect Bond movie (though it does have all the elements to be perfect), but it's still a fun, corny time. Definition of a popcorn movie.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Gert Fröbe, Honor Blackman
short_review: Gone is any and all idea of James Bond's vulnerability. However, "Goldfinger" swaps in a gaudier, glitzier subtext directly related to how this blockbuster took aim almost squarely at an American audience.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Carey Lowell, Robert Davi
short_review: The most brutal Bond film from the pre-Daniel Craig era.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Carey Lowell, Robert Davi
short_review: Licence to Kill is a different beast entirely. Violent, barbaric, and untamed - this was everything that James Bond decidedly was not. It was here that Dalton's ideal of Fleming's agent crystallized.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Carey Lowell, Robert Davi
short_review: The level of violence is unlike any other of the series, making the chief antagonist more formidable, memorable, and ultimately less fun.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Carey Lowell, Robert Davi
short_review: Daniel Craig shows the grit, the determination and vulnerability that Bond has...Dalton did that years before!

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Carey Lowell, Robert Davi
short_review: I think it's very underrated.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Carey Lowell, Robert Davi
short_review: It may not be up your alley if you're just into Bond films, but it you're in the mood for an old fashioned action film, you can do far, far worse than sticking this film on.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Carey Lowell, Robert Davi
short_review: Lacks a bit of that Bond magic. Perhaps not the cruder, formulaic elements of other Bond films, but the lightness of touch and inherent charm in the character of Bond himself.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Carey Lowell, Robert Davi
short_review: The movie is really well-structured, simple in plot but rather meaty in delivery.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Carey Lowell, Robert Davi
short_review: Some of 007's earlier adventures fail to hold up, but in a post-'Taken' world, 'Licence to Kill' certainly aged well and is a under-appreciated gem in the Bond catalog.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Carey Lowell, Robert Davi
short_review: Licence to Kill gets better as it unfolds for more than two hours. It just takes an insufferably long while to find the right pace.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Carey Lowell, Robert Davi
short_review: Licence to Kill ranks as one of the best of the 16 Bond films, thanks to Dalton's athletic, tough and deadly new 007.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Carey Lowell, Robert Davi
short_review: As unlikely as it seems, Mr. Dalton actually appears to be growing in the Bond role, which is potentially stifling because its own popularity has so rigidly defined it.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Carey Lowell, Robert Davi
short_review: This series' record of maintaining an admirable level of quality stays intact, even if this film might best be used as a cinematic appetizer to see before renting a tape of one of the Connery or Moore classics.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Carey Lowell, Robert Davi
short_review: Every once in a while, [the Bond series] pulls in its stomach, pops the gun from its cummerbund, arches its eyebrow and gets off another bull's-eye. The newest, Licence to Kill, is probably one of the five or six best of Bond.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Carey Lowell, Robert Davi
short_review: He may look the part, but Timothy Dalton fails the boots, the scuba gear, or the automobiles left him by Moore and Connery.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Carey Lowell, Robert Davi
short_review: If the series is ever going to return to its Connery-era glory, it definitely needs some new writers, ones who know how to streamline a story and keep the dialogue tight.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Carey Lowell, Robert Davi
short_review: Dalton revives the cool, ironic detachment of the Connery years, but he also allows a touch of obsession to show through Bond`s surface aplomb.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Carey Lowell, Robert Davi
short_review: With Dalton straightening out Bond for the second time, Licence to Kill continues the salvage operation begun in The Living Daylights and rescues a series that was in danger of shooting itself in the foot. With a Walther PPK, of course.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Carey Lowell, Robert Davi
short_review: It's a watchable adventure boosted by impressive action sequences and a fiery climax with a bone-crunching punch-up. Pity Dalton didn't have another crack at proving his secret-agent credentials.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Carey Lowell, Robert Davi
short_review: Darker version of James Bond has more violence, language.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Yaphet Kotto, Jane Seymour
short_review: This introduces the worst -- I repeat, worst -- character to be found in any Bond movie.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Yaphet Kotto, Jane Seymour
short_review: Will James Bond live on in the 1970s? Not much farther, if this episode is anything to go by.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Yaphet Kotto, Jane Seymour
short_review: It is good, lively, mindless entertainment, slow to warm up but once embarked upon its improbable story quick to appreciate its own absurdity.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Yaphet Kotto, Jane Seymour
short_review: Live and Let Die's flaws are apparent, but it's still a solid adventure, and Moore fits smoothly into the role of Bond. It's an enjoyable film, and that's really all you could ask for.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Yaphet Kotto, Jane Seymour
short_review: Considering the blandness of this eighth theatrical chapter, it's miraculous that further adventures would make it to the big screen.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Yaphet Kotto, Jane Seymour
short_review: If Live and Let Die was Moore's acid test, then he passed the test.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Yaphet Kotto, Jane Seymour
short_review: While [Bond's] latest adventure looks as though his producers had trimmed a few million dollars off the budget, it is still fast, funny and frivolous enough to satisfy.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Yaphet Kotto, Jane Seymour
short_review: Stands as proof to the maxim that James Bond and the 1970s simply didn't mix.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Yaphet Kotto, Jane Seymour
short_review: Far from the worse offender in Roger Moore's outings as Bond. A boring boat chase and a slapstick final fate for our villain definitely takes it down a peg or two though...

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Yaphet Kotto, Jane Seymour
short_review: If you want to see an out of place Bond effort that would have been vastly improved with Shaft or Superfly in the lead role instead of 007, give this a view.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Yaphet Kotto, Jane Seymour
short_review: There are some splendid action sequences, notably a speedboat leap that set a new world record, as well as the usual array of hi-tech gadgetry.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Yaphet Kotto, Jane Seymour
short_review: As fastpaced and snappily entertaining a piece of claptrap as we have a right to expect.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Yaphet Kotto, Jane Seymour
short_review: So-so '70s Bond entry has sex, drugs, action violence.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Yaphet Kotto, Jane Seymour
short_review: I can see how many people can be entertained by this ludicrous film, but not because it's good. It features an outstanding performance from Moore and has an enjoyably bad Blaxploitation thing going on here, but not much else.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Yaphet Kotto, Jane Seymour
short_review: Roger Moore's first 007 job is still top entertainment.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Yaphet Kotto, Jane Seymour
short_review: In the longest tenure of any James Bond performer, Roger Moore would certainly have higher highs and lower lows. And while it strays from Bond formula in ways good and bad, it's a fine introduction to a 007 more prone to crack wise than crack heads.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Yaphet Kotto, Jane Seymour
short_review: The first outright terrible Bond picture.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Yaphet Kotto, Jane Seymour
short_review: Tacky and cartoonish.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Yaphet Kotto, Jane Seymour
short_review: I know I probably shouldn't like Live and Let Die, but I do. This crackpot entry, the eighth, in the long-running James Bond series, is figuratively all over the map...[Blu-ray]

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Yaphet Kotto, Jane Seymour
short_review: Guy Hamilton's direction lacks enthusiasm and pace, while even the art direction -- long the Bond films' real secret weapon -- seems to have fallen to a shrunken budget.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Maryam D'Abo, Jeroen Krabbé
short_review: Timothy Dalton's series debut is classic Cold War Bond, and grade-A spy stuff.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Maryam D'Abo, Jeroen Krabbé
short_review: ...marks one of those moments when the Bond franchise was awkwardly caught between two eras.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Maryam D'Abo, Jeroen Krabbé
short_review: The Living Daylights is extraordinary. The greatest Bond Actor gets an auspicious debut, harkening back to the strengths of Fleming and offering a richly detailed excursion in the world of 007.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Maryam D'Abo, Jeroen Krabbé
short_review: Smartly, it kickstarts a grander daredevilry in Bond films - and a greater realism in the violence - that is entirely welcome.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Maryam D'Abo, Jeroen Krabbé
short_review: The Living Daylights breathes new life into the series and we needed that.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Maryam D'Abo, Jeroen Krabbé
short_review: If you're looking for a bit for fun in your Bond film, this would be one to skip, otherwise it's a really good action film with some top class set pieces.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Maryam D'Abo, Jeroen Krabbé
short_review: While the film seemed relatively modern well into the '90s, now it is a bygone era for which I'm nostalgic.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Maryam D'Abo, Jeroen Krabbé
short_review: Dalton's Bond brings the British spy much closer to the head and heart of a real character.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Maryam D'Abo, Jeroen Krabbé
short_review: Just what the franchise needed to become more culturally relevant as the 1990s approached.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Maryam D'Abo, Jeroen Krabbé
short_review: I feel just rotten about this, but I'm afraid I've outgrown James.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Maryam D'Abo, Jeroen Krabbé
short_review: In The Living Daylights, Dalton establishes his claim to the role; in the films that will follow, he'll have the chance to dig deeper.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Maryam D'Abo, Jeroen Krabbé
short_review: The relative clarity of the story allows director John Glen and screenwriters Richard Maibaum and Michael G. Wilson to inject moments of subtlety and human interest -- commodities that in recent Bonds have been in even shorter supply than sense.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Maryam D'Abo, Jeroen Krabbé
short_review: Why not send James off to well-earned retirement with a gold-plated martini shaker and the thanks of a grateful moviegoing public?

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Maryam D'Abo, Jeroen Krabbé
short_review: Despite being hampered by an overly convoluted plot and two of the feeblest Bond villains ever (greedy buffoons Koskov and Whitaker don't have a quantum of menace between them), Dalton brings much-needed grit to the role.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Maryam D'Abo, Jeroen Krabbé
short_review: Dalton shows a serious side that's been missing from the role since Sean Connery's earliest 007 days. And as a whole, the new picture is less of a special-effects affair than most of Roger Moore's Bond films.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Maryam D'Abo, Jeroen Krabbé
short_review: This was Timothy Dalton's debut as 007 and it was already pretty clear that he lacked the necessary ironic touch that made the credibility-straining action seem fun rather than ridiculous.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Maryam D'Abo, Jeroen Krabbé
short_review: Bond is impersonated by 007 newcomer Timothy Dalton, who does little that's identifiable as acting, although he looks the part.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Maryam D'Abo, Jeroen Krabbé
short_review: As with other Bond movies, the locations in The Living Daylights are more remarkable than its plot.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Maryam D'Abo, Jeroen Krabbé
short_review: Colorful, vibrant, exotic, The Living Daylights more than delivers an eyeful of entertainment. At a running length just over two hours, the most thrill- seeking Bond fans will get their money`s worth.

movie_cast: Timothy Dalton, Maryam D'Abo, Jeroen Krabbé
short_review: The result is a film that is not so much bad as mechanical and uptight.

movie_title: The Man With the Golden Gun

movie_title: The Man With the Golden Gun

movie_title: The Man With the Golden Gun

short_review: Moore (in only his second try at Bond) gets to be extremely unconvincing as a martial artist, though somewhat believable as a frequent escaper.

movie_title: The Man With the Golden Gun
movie_cast: Roger Moore, Christopher Lee, Britt Ekland
short_review: I love Roger Moore. I grew up on him as Bond. But in The Man with the Golden Gun, you can tell he hasn't settled into making Bond his own.

movie_title: The Man With the Golden Gun
movie_cast: Roger Moore, Christopher Lee, Britt Ekland
short_review: The producers seem intent on destroying a money-making business.

movie_title: The Man With the Golden Gun
movie_cast: Roger Moore, Christopher Lee, Britt Ekland
short_review: One of the real Bond curios and arguably the most passable Roger Moore entrant to the entire series.

movie_title: The Man With the Golden Gun
movie_cast: Roger Moore, Christopher Lee, Britt Ekland
short_review: The latest and least in the James Bond series.

movie_title: The Man With the Golden Gun
movie_cast: Roger Moore, Christopher Lee, Britt Ekland
short_review: Had so much wasted potential. Scaramanga was a great villain, both written and played, but everything else surrounding him in the movie is... well... bad.

movie_title: The Man With the Golden Gun
movie_cast: Roger Moore, Christopher Lee, Britt Ekland
short_review: Perfectly embodying the best and worst of the Roger Moore 007 era, this is a fun Bond adventure that ultimately fails to fully meet its potential.

movie_title: The Man With the Golden Gun
movie_cast: Roger Moore, Christopher Lee, Britt Ekland
short_review: Merely another Bond film.

movie_title: The Man With the Golden Gun
movie_cast: Roger Moore, Christopher Lee, Britt Ekland
short_review: This is an improvement on Ian Fleming's novel, with Christopher Lee making a fine villain.

movie_title: The Man With the Golden Gun
movie_cast: Roger Moore, Christopher Lee, Britt Ekland
short_review: For this movie 007's license to thrill had definitely been revoked.

movie_title: The Man With the Golden Gun

short_review: [Lee] gives a performance that will endure long after the rest of the film is forgotten; he is its meaning and purpose, towering over its cartoon action, reducing even 007 to a footnote.

movie_title: The Man With the Golden Gun
movie_cast: Roger Moore, Christopher Lee, Britt Ekland
short_review: Action-packed Bond film has sexual situations, shooting.

movie_title: The Man With the Golden Gun
movie_cast: Roger Moore, Christopher Lee, Britt Ekland
short_review: This one has all the right ingredients to be a great Bond flick, I mean Christopher Lee is the main villain! I don't exactly know how they screwed this up, but they did.

movie_title: The Man With the Golden Gun
movie_cast: Roger Moore, Christopher Lee, Britt Ekland
short_review: This is Bond by numbers: the fast cars, fast boats and fast women are all here, but there's little imagination at work.

movie_title: The Man With the Golden Gun
movie_cast: Roger Moore, Christopher Lee, Britt Ekland
short_review: Why did a tale that could've been a bit ragged - and a nice stretch for Moore - become simply a so-so romp? Chalk it up to the franchise's nervous need to capitalize on other genres' zeitgeist -first, blaxploitation, and here, martial arts.

movie_title: The Man With the Golden Gun
movie_cast: Roger Moore, Christopher Lee, Britt Ekland
short_review: Perhaps the most inconsistent of all James Bond pictures, with some outstanding moments and sequences sitting quite blithely next to absolute rancidity.

movie_title: The Man With the Golden Gun
movie_cast: Roger Moore, Christopher Lee, Britt Ekland
short_review: the first film that actually allowed Moore to get into the role without having to live up to Connery

movie_title: The Man With the Golden Gun
movie_cast: Roger Moore, Christopher Lee, Britt Ekland
short_review: A diverting but typically silly Roger Moore entry in the Bond canon. [Blu-ray]

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Klaus Maria Brandauer, Barbara Carrera
short_review: This is basically Thunderball under a new moniker. It bests its predecessor in most regards.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Klaus Maria Brandauer, Barbara Carrera
short_review: The film stands up well on its own, and there's the added value of Connery, gifted with one last go at the role that catapulted him to superstardom.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Klaus Maria Brandauer, Barbara Carrera
short_review: It may be Bond, but without the use of the gun barrel graphics, the booming theme music, and the opening title silhouettes of nude figures, it just doesn't feel the same.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Klaus Maria Brandauer, Barbara Carrera
short_review: Adding together a marvellous array of sophistication, comedy and action. Never Say Never Again is superb entertainment.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Klaus Maria Brandauer, Barbara Carrera
short_review: Overall I liked Never Say Never Again but it fell far short of the movie it could have been. The makers should have been more adventurous instead of simply trying to beat Broccoli at his own game.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Klaus Maria Brandauer, Barbara Carrera
short_review: Everything is more implausible and entertaining, even though the structure is the same. [Full Review in Spanish]

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Klaus Maria Brandauer, Barbara Carrera
short_review: Superior to 'Octopussy', it shows that Connery is, for the moment, the actor who best treated the character, the only one who even took it seriously, possessed the necessary humor to make us laugh at him. [Full Review in Spanish]

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Klaus Maria Brandauer, Barbara Carrera
