movie_cast: Sean Connery, Klaus Maria Brandauer, Barbara Carrera
short_review: If you haven't seen 'Thunderball,' this is a lot more enjoyable, but matched up against one of the more exciting 007 films, 'Never Say Never' fails to do it better.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Klaus Maria Brandauer, Barbara Carrera
short_review: Never Say Never Again is the best acted Bond picture ever made, because it clearly surpasses any predecessors in the area of inventive and clever character delineation.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Klaus Maria Brandauer, Barbara Carrera
short_review: It's not a rap against Roger Moore to say that this film seems to bring James Bond back to life. Sean Connery did, after all, define the character.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Klaus Maria Brandauer, Barbara Carrera
short_review: Sean Connery is still up to par as James Bond in the latest adventure of Agent 007.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Klaus Maria Brandauer, Barbara Carrera
short_review: The plot, which owes much to Thunderball, lurches badly at times, but the wild action set pieces, decked out in gals, gadgets and glib lines, are there to be cherished.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Klaus Maria Brandauer, Barbara Carrera
short_review: A fitting farewell to 007's most enduring embodiment: as much a playful send-up as a loving final embrace.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Klaus Maria Brandauer, Barbara Carrera
short_review: Can we just consider 1983 a lost year for James Bond? First, "Octopussy," then Sean Connery's return in a depressing dilution of the 007 brand - one that ends with a fourth wall-breaking wink indicative less of arch fun, more of bored indifference.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Klaus Maria Brandauer, Barbara Carrera
short_review: I know Bond fans were furious about this movie cause it wasn't an Eon production, and I think they're wrong. They should be furious at it because it's a horrendous film.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Klaus Maria Brandauer, Barbara Carrera
short_review: The slick production values impress and Barbara Carrera and Klaus Maria Brandauer are good value villains, but Irvin Kershner appears to have nodded off in the director's chair.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Klaus Maria Brandauer, Barbara Carrera
short_review: In Never Say Never Again, the formula is broadened to accommodate an older, seasoned man of much greater stature, and Mr. Connery expertly fills the bill.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Klaus Maria Brandauer, Barbara Carrera
short_review: An ugly, unwanted epilogue [to Connery's Bond], in which the character who was so iconic and perfect is reduced to a self-conscious joke.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Klaus Maria Brandauer, Barbara Carrera
short_review: There is a special place in movie hell for Never Say Never Again. Not that it's particularly bad -- though it's hardly good -- but because it's such a cheeseball experience with a strange and horrible pedigree.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Rami Malek, Léa Seydoux
short_review: No Time to Die's pieces are all there, but its execution is slightly underwhelming... When it works, it works. It's just not as good as it could have been, and that's slightly disappointing.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Rami Malek, Léa Seydoux
short_review: Lashana Lynch is a total blast as the MI6 agent Nomi, both a worthy rival for Bond as well as a potential replacement.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Rami Malek, Léa Seydoux
short_review: A very silly movie wrapped in serious clothes, saved single-handedly by Daniel Craig's raw, wounded performance.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Rami Malek, Léa Seydoux
short_review: More indulgent and exhausting than entertaining.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Rami Malek, Léa Seydoux
short_review: After 15 years and five films Daniel Craig has retired from the role that brought him international fame. Almost certainly unwittingly, Craig will also be associated with the demise of James Bond as we knew him.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Rami Malek, Léa Seydoux
short_review: ... fails to live up to the potential of (Casino) Royale and Skyfall, undermining this Bond series-within-a-series; Craig nevertheless wrings every ounce of anger and angst out of the super spy, making his portrayal an impossible act to follow.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Rami Malek, Léa Seydoux
short_review: [No Time To Die] begins inside a memory and ends with a kind of apocalypse. Sound familiar? Not really. Memory has never been a prominent theme in the series, and the mood of this instalment is different in many ways.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Rami Malek, Léa Seydoux
short_review: And in a welcome surprise - assertive women show up in an impressive triumvirate of Ana de Armas, Lashana Lynch and Lea Seydoux.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Rami Malek, Léa Seydoux
short_review: While the motivations, or at least the back stories, of some of the characters are less than clear, the story works well enough for an action film with a lot more heart and soul than is usual in this series.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Rami Malek, Léa Seydoux
short_review: No Time to Die looks and feels like a Skyfall while playing like a Spectre-good and bad comingling in a way that's almost fitting.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Rami Malek, Léa Seydoux
short_review: In the best Bond tradition... offers up implausibilities with shameless abandon, like a helpful bartender serving one martini after another, fully aware that each serving is dulling your critical thinking skills.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Rami Malek, Léa Seydoux
short_review: Daniel Craig's Bonds are not a bad place to start with [the character]. His Bond feels real, relevant to this time and immediate.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Rami Malek, Léa Seydoux
short_review: Fans will enjoy seeing Bond's non-stop hand-to-hand combat and his iconic driving skills--cinematography is stunning.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Rami Malek, Léa Seydoux
short_review: The last with Daniel Craig in the lead, the film brings together the various aspects of his nonconformist interpretation of James Bond in a most satisfying way.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Rami Malek, Léa Seydoux
short_review: The film's sole distinction is the fact that it's the James Bond epic that finally manages to make 007 a crashing bore.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Rami Malek, Léa Seydoux
short_review: With this fifth and final go-round, it's clear who the best Bond is. It's Craig, Daniel Craig.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Rami Malek, Léa Seydoux
short_review: Absolutely faithful to the Bondian canon, Cary Jonji Fukunaga's film brings the series full circle. [Full Review in Spanish]

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Rami Malek, Léa Seydoux
short_review: Too long, too complex script-wise, but still entertaining. It's Bond!

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Rami Malek, Léa Seydoux
short_review: A decent farewell to Craig's Bond. It is a bit too lengthy. I wish there was more Ana de Armas, she was a standout.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Rami Malek, Léa Seydoux
short_review: Sophisticated entertainment, as well as poignant reflexion on bioweapons, fallible heroes, and love.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Maud Adams, Louis Jourdan
short_review: I've seen the Bond movies countless times over the decades, and this title above all is the one that fluctuates the most from one viewing to the next.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Maud Adams, Louis Jourdan
short_review: It's an easy film to hate (and often paints a big target on its back encouraging you to do so), but it works perfectly as a piece of entertainment, where the good ultimately outweighs the bad.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Maud Adams, Louis Jourdan
short_review: For the first time in the series, the story unfolds like a true mystery, instead of merely having some eccentric billionaire devising a plot to take over the world.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Maud Adams, Louis Jourdan
short_review: Out of all the Roger Moore films as Bond, this one is easily the worse for me.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Maud Adams, Louis Jourdan
short_review: The naffness that was prevalent in the Bond series around the time of Moore still abounds here.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Maud Adams, Louis Jourdan
short_review: The very worst Roger Moore Bond Film, and one to avoid unless you really have to watch every single film in a marathon, like myself, sadly...

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Maud Adams, Louis Jourdan
short_review: "Octopussy" is the 13th of the James Bond movies, and it is one of the best.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Maud Adams, Louis Jourdan
short_review: Considering Bond gets disguised as an ape, a crocodile and a clown, the film has a lot more to be embarrassed about than its title.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Maud Adams, Louis Jourdan
short_review: It's a pleasure to report that the James Bond company is confidently back on the beam.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Maud Adams, Louis Jourdan
short_review: This was the 13th Bond movie and it's possibly the most frivolous in the series to date (it's certainly the most careless).

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Maud Adams, Louis Jourdan
short_review: [Director John Glen] keeps the excitement level high for an hour or so, then lets the show slip into the doldrums.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Maud Adams, Louis Jourdan
short_review: A solid action movie without the variety show camp of Moonraker, Octopussy (shock, horror) may well the best of the Moores.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Maud Adams, Louis Jourdan
short_review: While this film is not up to the level of Goldfinger or Live and Let Die, it is still first-class escapist entertainment.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Maud Adams, Louis Jourdan
short_review: More sexual innuendo than usual in provocatively named film.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Maud Adams, Louis Jourdan
short_review: Octopussy features 2 stand-out action sequences but for the most part, it's an overlong, sluggish, and schizophrenic entry in the Bond series.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Maud Adams, Louis Jourdan
short_review: James Bond is old. Wrinkled-forehead old. Lecherous-coot old. Strategic-hairstyle old. Senior meal-discount old. Simply ... old. That's the biggest takeaway from Roger Moore's second-worst outing as 007, hot on the heels of his second-best.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Maud Adams, Louis Jourdan
short_review: While the film is the first of the genuinely bloated Bond movies, it only rarely drags.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Maud Adams, Louis Jourdan
short_review: Bottom-drawer Bond.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Maud Adams, Louis Jourdan
short_review: Glen's willingness to give the action sequences a certain weight and seriousness produces some genuinely exciting moments, yet his work is everywhere undermined by the flatness of the characterizations and the uncertain architecture of the plot.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Maud Adams, Louis Jourdan
short_review: Little is added that departs from the Bond formula.

movie_cast: George Lazenby, Diana Rigg, Telly Savalas
short_review: You won't find a more tragic ending in any Bond flick.

movie_cast: George Lazenby, Diana Rigg, Telly Savalas
short_review: Savalas makes a great Bond villain here as the notorious Blofeld.

movie_cast: George Lazenby, Diana Rigg, Telly Savalas
short_review: On Her Majesty's Secret Service is pure poetry. It transcends the idea of a Bond film. Gorgeously photographed, thrillingly executed, and wonderfully performed, this is the franchise zenith.

movie_cast: George Lazenby, Diana Rigg, Telly Savalas
short_review: While trying to include all of the expected constituents of a Bond picture, many elements actually slow down the pacing - creating the longest runtime yet.

movie_cast: George Lazenby, Diana Rigg, Telly Savalas
short_review: On Her Majesty's Secret Service is the quintessential Bond film.

movie_cast: George Lazenby, Diana Rigg, Telly Savalas
short_review: The movie follows, almost too much, the exact same format of Bond flicks of the mid-sixties, and shows nothing new in character development or film technique.

movie_cast: George Lazenby, Diana Rigg, Telly Savalas
short_review: One of the best Bond movies of the entire series: it features cracking cinematography and there are some stupendous action sequences.

movie_cast: George Lazenby, Diana Rigg, Telly Savalas
short_review: The single most emotionally charged and unexpectedly fulfilling entry in the entire [Bond] series.

movie_cast: George Lazenby, Diana Rigg, Telly Savalas
short_review: Falls in the middle of the scale, it's not the worse, it's not the best, it's just a mix of both, just with a Bond who is often not very interesting to watch on screen...

movie_cast: George Lazenby, Diana Rigg, Telly Savalas
short_review: The dehumanising of Bond has reached a point where pain has become the last irrelevance and he soaks up punishment with the dreadful willingness of a cartoon cat.

movie_cast: George Lazenby, Diana Rigg, Telly Savalas
short_review: The sixth outing for 007 is a magnificently memorable adventure that sees Bond out to stop the dispersal of a killer virus by a bevy of beauties brainwashed by Telly Savalas's villainous Blofeld.

movie_cast: George Lazenby, Diana Rigg, Telly Savalas
short_review: Essential Bond viewing. It should definitely be among the five Bond films to make someone a fan of the series.

movie_cast: George Lazenby, Diana Rigg, Telly Savalas
short_review: Artistically, Bond's sixth entry, the only one to star Aussie George Lazenby, is much better than given credit to, though commercially it was one of the weakest.

movie_cast: George Lazenby, Diana Rigg, Telly Savalas
short_review: [Concentrates] more on the man than the equipment.

movie_cast: George Lazenby, Diana Rigg, Telly Savalas
short_review: Besides not being a terribly good Bond entry, it's also a poorly made film.

movie_cast: George Lazenby, Diana Rigg, Telly Savalas
short_review: An odd interruption in the Bond canon that's neither an unsung masterpiece nor an unmitigated disaster. It's half terrific, half terrible -the former most often when George Lazenby shuts up and Peter Hunt's masterful action instincts take over.

movie_cast: George Lazenby, Diana Rigg, Telly Savalas
short_review: Even hobbled as he is by a character he doesn't entirely get, and Peter Hunt's antagonistic direction, and the film's annoying tendency to remind us of Connery... George azenby puts up a good fight.

movie_cast: George Lazenby, Diana Rigg, Telly Savalas
short_review: 007 in ski country -- and marriage territory?

movie_cast: George Lazenby, Diana Rigg, Telly Savalas
short_review: Just as entertaining and as visually attractive as the five previous Bond films.

movie_cast: George Lazenby, Diana Rigg, Telly Savalas
short_review: Film of break-neck physical excitement and stunning visual attractions in which George Lazenby replaced Sean Connery as James Bond.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Olga Kurylenko, Mathieu Amalric
short_review: Daniel Craig remains dutiful as ever, but following the franchise zenith that is Casino Royale, this should have been a lot better.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Olga Kurylenko, Mathieu Amalric
short_review: Quantum of Solace isn't a bad film but it must be watched with the understanding that it was rushed into production to avoid a potential SAG strike.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Olga Kurylenko, Mathieu Amalric
short_review: Casino Royale was a spectacular return to form, so it's not wholly unexpected that this follow-up has been tagged by some as one of the low points of the franchise. Nonsense.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Olga Kurylenko, Mathieu Amalric
short_review: Starts off alright but slowly becomes less and less interesting until it suddenly ends, plus the villain is more "mildly annoying prick" than Bond's big enemy...

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Olga Kurylenko, Mathieu Amalric
short_review: It's not the first Bond film to fall back into a rut that will require the changing of the lead actor to get out of.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Olga Kurylenko, Mathieu Amalric
short_review: I don't mind losing the groan-inducing puns and the gimmicky gadgets, but strip Bond down too much and he begins to resemble Jason Bourne - and I'd rather have a first-rate Bond than a second-hand Bourne.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Olga Kurylenko, Mathieu Amalric
short_review: Quantum of Solace is how I imagined the sequel to On Her Majesty's Secret Service if it came to fruition.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Olga Kurylenko, Mathieu Amalric
short_review: Quantum of Solace is one of the most listless Bond films I have seen.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Olga Kurylenko, Mathieu Amalric
short_review: Quantum of Solace has style, and enough pursuit and pyrotechnics to please hard-core Bond fans. But it may disappoint those hoping for Marc Forster's distinctive imprint and a return to Casino Royale's top form.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Olga Kurylenko, Mathieu Amalric
short_review: Bond is being further shaped into the character we've always known, and will most definitely be back to fight another day.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Olga Kurylenko, Mathieu Amalric
short_review: Unfairly maligned in relation to its more colourful and emotive cousins of the Daniel Craig era, Quantum of Solace is actually the more cerebral and challenging piece of work.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Olga Kurylenko, Mathieu Amalric
short_review: A plot of an unnecessarily complex development that fails miserably in something that its predecessor did very well: offer characters that seduce us. [Full Review in Spanish]

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Olga Kurylenko, Mathieu Amalric
short_review: This isn't a mindless blow-'em-up thriller, this is an intelligently crafted, superbly edited, lean, mean piece of work.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Olga Kurylenko, Mathieu Amalric
short_review: While it's understandable that long-term Bond devotees may be left pining for the days when the puns were a bit more plentiful, and the punches a bit less lethal, I for one hope they don't go too far back in the other direction.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Olga Kurylenko, Mathieu Amalric
short_review: The angsty, truant Bond and his sulky ways get too irritating, the pout notwithstanding.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Olga Kurylenko, Mathieu Amalric
short_review: Perhaps confusing the audience is what Forster meant when he said he was making an art house picture.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Olga Kurylenko, Mathieu Amalric
short_review: At the end of Solace there are a couple of unhappy but typical realizations: 1) that the film only runs 106 minutes when it seemed more like 166, and 2) that it's still hard to say whether Daniel Craig moves well as an action hero.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Olga Kurylenko, Mathieu Amalric
short_review: Somehow Marc Forster's direction sucks all the vitality out of the film. There's no thrill in the chase. With the exception of an absolutely first-rate fight sequence on scaffolding in a church under renovation, Bond is having no fun at all.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Olga Kurylenko, Mathieu Amalric
short_review: Kurylenko is certainly gorgeous, but can't match Craig as a thespian, and the necessary chemistry between them is merely mundane.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Olga Kurylenko, Mathieu Amalric
short_review: If they want to keep making movies like this with Daniel Craig as a British secret agent, I think they should at least change his name to something besides Bond.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Judi Dench, Javier Bardem
short_review: Skyfall is an immeasurably satisfying Bond film. Sumptuously photographed and terrifically executed, the film is a perfect valentine to the world of 007.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Judi Dench, Javier Bardem
short_review: Skyfall is an anniversary film and delivers on every note.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Judi Dench, Javier Bardem
short_review: This chapter does so much right.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Judi Dench, Javier Bardem
short_review: I do enjoy most of Skyfall, it has some great set pieces and a charismatic villain but some pacing issues hold it back for me. Still better than Quantum of Solace at least!

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Judi Dench, Javier Bardem
short_review: The film blended those new impulses with the franchise's old flourishes so well...

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Judi Dench, Javier Bardem
short_review: A rip-roaring action film, too, with elite direction, terrific lighting and editing, and strong work from a talented cast.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Judi Dench, Javier Bardem
short_review: It's also the first time anyone notices the cinematography in a Bond movie. Shanghai & Macao never looked better. Misty Scotland, backlit by burning mansion is perhaps second best this year, losing only to another Scottish movie, Wuthering Heights.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Judi Dench, Javier Bardem
short_review: The latest in 007's adventures is so far removed from the super spy's typical assignments that it often feels like only a hollow shell of the iconic hero.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Judi Dench, Javier Bardem
short_review: Ben Whishaw is a blast as the nerdish gadget dude who keeps Bond well equipped.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Judi Dench, Javier Bardem
short_review: Skyfall in a nutshell - respecting the past and yet ensuring that Bond lasts for another 50 years.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Judi Dench, Javier Bardem
short_review: The most personal Bond story since "On Her Majesty's Secret Service".

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Judi Dench, Javier Bardem
short_review: Rather than being a simple 'resurrection', it is the reinvention of 007. [Full review in Spanish]

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Judi Dench, Javier Bardem
short_review: Skyfall may not be an existential masterpiece, but it is a near perfect action thriller that features an excellent cast highlighted by a performance that should rank Raoul Silva as one of the best Bond villains of all time...

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Judi Dench, Javier Bardem
short_review: Mendes takes the bold extra step of challenging action audiences.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Judi Dench, Javier Bardem
short_review: Thrilling, smart yet slightly overlong, Skyfall is more than a film - it is a statement. Welcome back, Mr Bond.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Judi Dench, Javier Bardem
short_review: The character of Bond always works best when a blank canvas of nihilist tendencies and ultra-professionalism, so the Batman-style stab at populist pathos didn't wash with me.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Judi Dench, Javier Bardem
short_review: 'Skyfall' remains a powerful film, of immaculate and superb accomplishment, of inspired performances. [Full Review in Spanish]

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Judi Dench, Javier Bardem
short_review: Skyfall is a tad leaner on action, but it's certainly incredibly meaty on plot, glued together with the perfectly pitched tone and mood, and delivered with some delectable cinematography.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Judi Dench, Javier Bardem
short_review: The script, by Neal Purvis, Robert Wade and John Logan, is a study in contrast and pacing.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Judi Dench, Javier Bardem
short_review: A hugely entertaining adventure that takes Bond into previously uncharted territory, giving us everything we have come to expect from the 007 films and more.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Christoph Waltz, Léa Seydoux
short_review: Spectre is an immensely enjoyable Bond outing, that grows stronger with each passing viewing.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Christoph Waltz, Léa Seydoux
short_review: Daniel Craig's Bond story feels a little too sugary sweet for our beloved 007. Leave the happily ever afters for the fairytales, we came here for a movie about a spy.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Christoph Waltz, Léa Seydoux
short_review: Spectre never strays too far from the franchise formula but this action film is still a thrilling ride.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Christoph Waltz, Léa Seydoux
short_review: Spectre felt like loads of small ideas barely sewn together and a hasty attempt to make some sort of "ultimate villain" that doesn't work at all. Better than QoS at least...

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Christoph Waltz, Léa Seydoux
short_review: An engaging two hours are then run into the ground for a wince-inducing final half-hour of unfortunate developments.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Christoph Waltz, Léa Seydoux
short_review: How much you enjoy this may depend on how you feel about Bond in general. If you miss the old days, with the world in elaborate peril and everything done with a big wink, this is a solid example of that.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Christoph Waltz, Léa Seydoux
short_review: Spectre, despite looking for all the world like a regressive throwback to Bond-eras passed, could end up pointing the way forward more acutely than we ever realised.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Christoph Waltz, Léa Seydoux
short_review: Daniel Craig has been a satisfying James Bond, but the films he's been put into have been, on average, far weaker than anything from the Connery, Moore, or Brosnan eras with this likely being the worst Craig film to date.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Christoph Waltz, Léa Seydoux
short_review: Great attention is given to making the CG disappear in favor of practical effects and authentic destruction, bringing back the amusement of older 007 adventures.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Christoph Waltz, Léa Seydoux
short_review: It's certainly not the worst Bond film in the world but it definitely misses the mark of being one of the best.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Christoph Waltz, Léa Seydoux
short_review: Like its predecessor, this is a densely-plotted thriller punctuated by exciting action sequences...The plot does get a little ahead of itself a few times, but it's pretty quick to recover and get things back on track.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Christoph Waltz, Léa Seydoux
short_review: Though it's a paint-by-numbers "James Bond movie," Spectre is still a James Bond movie, and as such, it's a pretty good time.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Christoph Waltz, Léa Seydoux
short_review: Despite its flaws, Spectre is a very engaging and entertaining film. [Full review in Spanish]

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Christoph Waltz, Léa Seydoux
short_review: It feels different with the visual style and the splendid music, but at the same time there is an imbalance that operates with the archaic clichés of 007 that worn the franchise so much and that don't fit with Craig's Bond. [Full review in Spanish]

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Christoph Waltz, Léa Seydoux
short_review: If you like Bond movies, you'll like it.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Christoph Waltz, Léa Seydoux
short_review: I thought it was really fun.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Christoph Waltz, Léa Seydoux
short_review: If SKYFALL was the film to make old-school Bond retro and acceptable rather than passe and anachronistic, then SPECTRE embraces it wholeheartedly. As entertaining as SKYFALL was (and SPECTRE is at times), it seems you reap what you sow.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Christoph Waltz, Léa Seydoux
short_review: Craig has one last chance to beat the odds with the 25th adventure. The phrase, "James Bond Will Return" is at the end of the credits. Let's hope it's a promise and not a threat.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Christoph Waltz, Léa Seydoux
short_review: The Mendes Bonds are beautiful, thrilling, funny, and sad. But Spectre takes on too much for ultimately too little return.

movie_cast: Daniel Craig, Christoph Waltz, Léa Seydoux
short_review: The producers have put $300 million into this Bond-stravaganza, so they need to feel like they're getting their money's worth. You probably will, too.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Barbara Bach, Curd Jürgens
short_review: An outstanding entry in the 007 franchise.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Barbara Bach, Curd Jürgens
short_review: If Roger Moore wasn't the best James Bond, he was at least the most honest.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Barbara Bach, Curd Jürgens
short_review: The Spy Who Loved Me re-establishes the greatness of the Bond franchise. It's the biggest and most boldly produced feature as of yet, offering bountiful thrills and fun in equal measure.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Barbara Bach, Curd Jürgens
short_review: On his tenth adventure, 007 is finally where he needs to be - in an entertaining movie deserving of his iconic image.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Barbara Bach, Curd Jürgens
short_review: The Spy Who Loved Me represents a new found energy for the franchise that was struggling for definition in the new decade. With amazing stunts and iconic moments, it's hard not to love this film.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Barbara Bach, Curd Jürgens
short_review: It really has hideously dated, from the gaudy fashion and special effects, to the smutty, sexist, 'Carry On'-style humour.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Barbara Bach, Curd Jürgens
short_review: If you want a fantastic voyage, and you've already seen Star Wars. the best trip in town is The Spy Who Loved Me.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Barbara Bach, Curd Jürgens
short_review: This installment features more creativity and fantasy than its predecessors. [Full Review in Spanish]

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Barbara Bach, Curd Jürgens
short_review: By no means a perfect film, but it was a very fun two hours, even if some of the fun was "fun because it was so bad" fun...

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Barbara Bach, Curd Jürgens
short_review: The Spy Who Loved Me had me at hello with the famous pre-title sequence culminating in the ski jump off the mountain.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Barbara Bach, Curd Jürgens
short_review: With a great villain, the series' definitive henchman, stunning Bond Babes, grand action and an all-time classic theme, this is a Bond film fully worthy of adoration.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Barbara Bach, Curd Jürgens
short_review: [The Spy Who Loved Me] gets off to a promising start but proves seriously deficient in staying power.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Barbara Bach, Curd Jürgens
short_review: This exceptional spy escapade is far-fetched mayhem of the highest order, with a welcome accent on character realism rather than just spectacular sets.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Barbara Bach, Curd Jürgens
short_review: It's good clean British fun.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Barbara Bach, Curd Jürgens
short_review: THE SPY WHO LOVED ME is not as good as I remembered it. All of its chases and action were much better in my memories. In reality, they're a bit lackluster.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Barbara Bach, Curd Jürgens
short_review: In a tremendous film that shows Moore's Bond still has the old razzle-dazzle, "Nobody Does It Better" isn't just a theme song. It's a forceful and fun statement of purpose, and "Spy" offers the franchise the definitive jolt it so sorely needed.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Barbara Bach, Curd Jürgens
short_review: The best combination of japery and seriousness, without descending into the clowning that would be a part of all but one of Moore's subsequent adventures [as Bond].

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Barbara Bach, Curd Jürgens
short_review: 1977's 007 still gettin' lucky in underwater lair.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Barbara Bach, Curd Jürgens
short_review: Overwhelmed with its cartoonish absurdity.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Barbara Bach, Curd Jürgens
short_review: Never did top that first stunt.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Claudine Auger, Adolfo Celi
short_review: The most overrated movie in the franchise. Of course, it's not without its merits.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Claudine Auger, Adolfo Celi

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Claudine Auger, Adolfo Celi

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Claudine Auger, Adolfo Celi
short_review: In addition to the physical machines there is a lot of deus ex-machina involved too, but only a critic would carp about that. Just go to watch the most remarkable things.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Claudine Auger, Adolfo Celi

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Claudine Auger, Adolfo Celi
short_review: Terence Young's direction is nothing if not taut, whisking the narrative along with the speed and precision of a jet plane, defying one to express boredom.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Claudine Auger, Adolfo Celi
short_review: The fourth, most commercially successful Bond to date, is known for its pre-credits sequences, underwater battles, and escalating number of violent deaths.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Claudine Auger, Adolfo Celi
short_review: Connery's Bond was never better than this.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Claudine Auger, Adolfo Celi
short_review: The ambition is evident throughout, but the execution just doesn't have enough energy to sustain it. THUNDERBALL is very sluggish.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Claudine Auger, Adolfo Celi

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Claudine Auger, Adolfo Celi
short_review: A particularly energetic, jaunty Bond adventure, the kind that is just plain fun to watch, in a perfectly relaxed and undemanding register.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Claudine Auger, Adolfo Celi
short_review: Even James Bond can miss his mark.

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Claudine Auger, Adolfo Celi
short_review: Thunderball, the biggest, most lavish, and longest Bond film at that time, was the most popular of its day.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Jonathan Pryce, Michelle Yeoh
short_review: Tomorrow Never Dies manages what always seemed impossible: It makes a Bond movie boring.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Jonathan Pryce, Michelle Yeoh
short_review: Tomorrow Never Die has its moments, but the film ultimately suffers from a lack of imagination, hastily going through the Bond motions without ever leaving much of an impact.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Jonathan Pryce, Michelle Yeoh
short_review: The action sequences are routinely stupendous, even if the storyline is enormously unmemorable.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Jonathan Pryce, Michelle Yeoh
short_review: How do you top Goldeneye? Unfortunately not with this effort.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Jonathan Pryce, Michelle Yeoh
short_review: Tomorrow Never Dies falls more towards the average thanks to a thin plot and an entertaining but extremely plain villain. Not bad, not great, just... fine.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Jonathan Pryce, Michelle Yeoh
short_review: It's really just a techno-action movie (and a crap one at that) paying lipservice to the conventions of the Bond movie.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Jonathan Pryce, Michelle Yeoh
short_review: As Bonds go, though, Tomorrow Never Dies is pleasant enough brain candy, although Brosnan's efforts deserve better... maybe next time, Meester Bond.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Jonathan Pryce, Michelle Yeoh

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Jonathan Pryce, Michelle Yeoh
short_review: Despite the film's faults, David Arnold's score, which layers industrialised sounds over traditional orchestration, can make some sequences seem more exciting than they actually are.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Jonathan Pryce, Michelle Yeoh
short_review: Brosnan gives it his best and with Yeoh, he's got a capable dance partner, but this 007 edition felt like a retread story that was already old news.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Jonathan Pryce, Michelle Yeoh
short_review: Tomorrow Never Dies is as overproduced as one of Carver's cable broadcasts -- incredibly noisy, flashy and busy without being terribly exciting.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Jonathan Pryce, Michelle Yeoh
short_review: Flaws aside, this was at the time the best Bond movie since the heyday of Mr Connery.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Jonathan Pryce, Michelle Yeoh
short_review: After weeks of media bombardment with Tomorrow Never Dies product tie-in commercials, it's clear that the studio and the film's producers have reinvented movie promotion. Now they need to focus their efforts on reinventing the Bond movies.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Jonathan Pryce, Michelle Yeoh
short_review: From the carnage of a troubled shoot emerged Brosnan's best Bond, striking the correct balance of menace, thrills and humour, using a chase-movie template to ensure attention never wavers.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Jonathan Pryce, Michelle Yeoh
short_review: Brosnan cements his reputation as the best James Bond since Sean Connery, and sometimes he even gives the master a run for his money.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Jonathan Pryce, Michelle Yeoh
short_review: Good news is, Tomorrow Never Dies is highly entertaining. It will thrill novices and delight old-guard Bondphiles.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Jonathan Pryce, Michelle Yeoh
short_review: In Tomorrow Never Dies, the news is mostly good. And when it comes to movies, there's no news like good news.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Jonathan Pryce, Michelle Yeoh
short_review: In the latest James Bond, our hero saves the world from brand-name unawareness. Tomorrow Never Dies is a dramatized trade show; imagine Comdex or the Geneva Automobile Salon with a plot.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Jonathan Pryce, Michelle Yeoh
short_review: Yeoh proves so much Bond's equal that they wind up sharing steering privileges on a death-defying motorcycle, her hand on the clutch and his on the brake, their other arms twined around each other. It's a pairing made in sequel heaven.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Jonathan Pryce, Michelle Yeoh
short_review: The good news in Tomorrow Never Dies is that Pierce Brosnan fills out James Bond's tux considerably better. In his second go at Bond, he seems tougher and less-lightweight.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Christopher Walken, Grace Jones
short_review: It features a killer Duran Duran theme song but strikes out in nearly every other regard.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Christopher Walken, Grace Jones
short_review: A View to a Kill is nowhere near as reviled as its reputation suggests. It might not be the proper send-off Roger Moore deserved, but the film has a great sense of fun, and its Villains are in a league of their own.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Christopher Walken, Grace Jones
short_review: The primary villain is memorably vicious and well acted, the henchmen and their demises are bombastic and amusing, and the set pieces are extravagantly grandiose.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Christopher Walken, Grace Jones
short_review: It will always be my ultimate guilty pleasure Bond film

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Christopher Walken, Grace Jones
short_review: Where other Bond films at least have a kitsch quality, A View to a Kill is not only silly but it also commits the ultimate cardinal sin for any Bond movie - it's boring.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Christopher Walken, Grace Jones
short_review: A good Bond film, filled with plenty of action and set pieces, with a great opening theme to boot! A solid note to go out on for Moore, even if he isn't a highlight himself...

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Christopher Walken, Grace Jones

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Christopher Walken, Grace Jones
short_review: While it doesn't reach its full potential, Roger Moore's final 007 outing is still a largely entertaining if admittedly flawed adventure.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Christopher Walken, Grace Jones
short_review: It's not double-oh-seven anymore, but double-oh-seventy, the best argument yet for the mandatory retirement age.

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Christopher Walken, Grace Jones

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Christopher Walken, Grace Jones

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Christopher Walken, Grace Jones

movie_cast: Roger Moore, Christopher Walken, Grace Jones
short_review: What says "outlandishly dumb action film from 1985" better than a plot to flood Silicon Valley and corner the world's microchip market?

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sophie Marceau, Robert Carlyle
short_review: It throws away good actors and sacrifices pace without providing any complexity in return

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sophie Marceau, Robert Carlyle

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sophie Marceau, Robert Carlyle

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sophie Marceau, Robert Carlyle

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sophie Marceau, Robert Carlyle

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sophie Marceau, Robert Carlyle
short_review: The World Is Not Enough is, pound for explosion pound, a great return on your entertainment dollar.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sophie Marceau, Robert Carlyle

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sophie Marceau, Robert Carlyle
short_review: At times it's slow and a bit too silly, but at its best, it's the worthy successor to 'GoldenEye' that Brosnan deserved.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sophie Marceau, Robert Carlyle
short_review: What happens this time around? You know exactly what happens: Bond shoots people, has sex and saves the world. The beauty is, as with most Bond movies, it doesn't matter.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sophie Marceau, Robert Carlyle
short_review: What do the James Bond series, the Chicago Cubs, and Master P's No Limit empire have in common? All owe their considerable commercial success more to loyalty, marketing, and tradition than to quality.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sophie Marceau, Robert Carlyle
short_review: We expect a rousing pre-credit sequence -- and The World Is Not Enough provides not one but two. Together they last 20 minutes and probably cost the GNP of an average Third World country.

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sophie Marceau, Robert Carlyle

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sophie Marceau, Robert Carlyle

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sophie Marceau, Robert Carlyle

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sophie Marceau, Robert Carlyle

movie_cast: Pierce Brosnan, Sophie Marceau, Robert Carlyle

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Akiko Wakabayashi, Donald Pleasence

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Akiko Wakabayashi, Donald Pleasence

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Akiko Wakabayashi, Donald Pleasence

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Akiko Wakabayashi, Donald Pleasence

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Akiko Wakabayashi, Donald Pleasence

movie_cast: Sean Connery, Akiko Wakabayashi, Donald Pleasence
